chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
And I saw, he said, a new heaven and a new earth. For the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and the sea was no more.

This will happen in the order that he previously mentioned, when he said he saw someone sitting on the throne, from whose face heaven and earth fled. Once the wicked are judged and condemned, the figure of this world will pass away in the conflagration of worldly fires, just as the flood happened by the inundation of worldly waters. With heaven and earth transformed for the better, the bodies of the saints will be suitably adapted to the new quality of both transformations with incorruption and immortality.

The world, renewed for the better, will be suitably adapted to men also renewed for the better.

But as for his statement: And the sea was no more, whether it will be dried up by that great heat, or even transformed for the better, I cannot easily say. For we read that there will be a new heaven and a new earth Isaiah 55. However, I do not recall reading anything about a new sea.

If perhaps, as is customary, prophetic speech mixes metaphors and veils what is said, he could have referred to that sea whose name is known to signify this turbulent and stormy mortal life. For at that time, this turbulent and stormy mortal life will no longer exist, which the name of the sea represented.

And he said, I saw the great city, the new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband. And I heard a loud voice from heaven saying: Behold, the dwelling place of God is with men, and he will dwell with them, and they will be his people, and God himself will be with them. And God will wipe away every tear from their eyes, and there will be no more death, nor mourning, nor crying, nor pain, for the former things have passed away.

And he who was seated on the throne said: Behold, I make all things new. This city is said to descend from heaven because it is by the heavenly grace that God made it, which is why he also says through Isaiah: I am the Lord who makes you Isaiah 45.
chunks.original_latin:

corpora congrua utriusque mutatione qualitate
conveniat, mundusque in melius innovatus, apte accommodetur
hominibus etiam in melius innovatis. Quod autem ait: Et mare jam non est, utrum maximo
illo ardore siccetur, an et ipsum vertatur in
melius, non facile dixerim. Coelum quippe novum
et terram novam futuram legimus (Isa LV). De

verbis translata miscere, ac si quodammodo

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
From heaven indeed, it descended from the beginning. Throughout this age, with the grace of God coming from above through the washing of regeneration in the Holy Spirit sent from heaven, its citizens continually increase. But through God's final judgment by His Son Jesus Christ, such great and new glory from God's gift will appear that no traces of oldness will remain, as even our bodies will transition from old corruption and mortality to new incorruption and immortality.

Hence, He promises, saying: God will wipe away every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more, neither will there be mourning, nor crying, nor pain anymore. All these things belong not to this life, but to the future life.

For now, in this life, the holier a person is and the fuller they are of holy desires, the more they excel in weeping during prayer. Hence, we read in Psalm 14: My tears have been my bread day and night, and in Psalm 46: I will wash my bed every night, and similar things.

And He said to me: These words are most faithful and true, and He said to me: It is done. These things must be believed, not explained, especially because He says it has been done in the past, so that no one may doubt the future.

I am Alpha and Omega, the first and the last. Just as He testified this at the beginning of the book, it had to be repeated in this third part, so that no one believes there is a God before Him, as Isaiah says in Isaiah 41, nor another after Him.

I will give to the thirsty from the fountain of the water of life freely. From this fountain, He waters the unbelievers on the way, offering them abundant drink in the homeland to those who conquer. So that the strangers in this desert may not fail from thirst, when they become citizens, they may be continually intoxicated from the torrent of God's delights. Both are free because, as the Apostle says in Romans 6, The grace of God is eternal life.

It follows: Whoever conquers will inherit these things, and I will be their God, and they will be my child. Here He remembers that generation, of which the Apostle says in Galatians 4: God sent the Spirit of His Son into our hearts, crying, Abba Father.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If we are children, then we are also heirs-heirs of God and co-heirs with Christ. But we have been saved by hope.

Romans chapter 8.

When hope brings us to reality, God Himself will be the reward of eternal happiness for the chosen ones, which they will possess forever. However, for the doubtful and the unbelievers,

this should be understood in this context, as mentioned by the Apostle James.

James chapter 1: "A double-minded man is unstable in all his ways."

And for the abominable, the murderers, the sexually immoral, the sorcerers, those who worship idols, and all liars, their part will be in the lake of fire which burns with sulfur, which is the second death.

These crimes and punishments should not simply be understood but rather considered on how to avoid them through God's grace.

And one of the seven angels, who had the seven bowls full of the last seven plagues, came and spoke to me.

Just as the number seven often represents completeness in good things, it can also represent the entirety of plagues in bad things.

If those mentioned earlier were poured out, now they are said to be full; it is surprising how the world stayed silent despite being afflicted.

Unless he preferred to briefly touch on what he had discussed in detail before, so as not to omit the mention of evils, and then quickly turn his attention to the good figure of the Church, about which it is sung.

Psalms chapter 27: "I believe I shall see the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living."

Finally, it continues: "And he spoke to me, saying: Come, I will show you the bride, the wife of the Lamb, which is the Church.

And he took me to a great and high mountain, and showed me the holy city, Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God.

"

This is, according to the testimony of Truth, the city set on a hill.

Matthew chapter 5.

Hence Isaiah chapter 2: "In the last days, the mountain of the Lord's house will be established as the highest of the mountains, and will be exalted above the hills.

"

Whether it is for the height of its righteousness about which we read.

Isaiah chapter 41: "Your righteousness is like the mighty mountains,"

or because mountains are often referred to as both apostles and prophets.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, the Lord Christ stands out above all, like a mountain at the peak of mountains. From His fullness, we have received grace upon grace.

And rightly so, from Heaven by God; it appears more beautiful when believed to be conceived and born through the Spirit, of which He is the bridegroom, deserving to bear the heavenly image.

Therefore, the bride, who is also the city, has the light of God's glory. To whom the Lord says in Matthew chapter 5: You are the light of the world. This voice applies to the whole body of Christ, which the apostles received from the mouth of Truth at that time and with prior merits.

And what illuminates her is like a most precious stone, like a jasper stone, shining like crystal.

Although jasper and crystal are different types and colors, due to their similarity, both are joined here and compared to the most precious stones. It was meant to be understood as revealed with Christ, of whom blessed Peter says in First Peter chapter 2: The stone, a precious cornerstone, laid in the foundation.

And it has a great and wide wall with twelve gates, and at the gates twelve angels, with names written of the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel.

The wall of the Church is Christ, whom we read as great and high. Great to the Lord and highly praised, in the city of our God, on His holy mountain, and the Lord is exalted above all nations. Psalms chapter 48, chapter 145, and chapter 113.

About the wall, the prophet Isaiah says in chapter 26: On that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah: Our city of strength is Zion; the Savior will place a wall and a rampart in it. Open the gates, and let the righteous nation, keeping the truth, enter; the old error has gone away.

Containing the same spirit, they seem to tell similar things. Finally, it follows about the gates, saying: And twelve gates, and at the gates twelve angels, and names written of the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel.

Indeed, we know that through the twelve apostles, our Lord provided the beginning of the entry to faith for everyone in different ways.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, the circumstances of this place have diverted us from our initial intention, as it mentions the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel. It seems to first refer to the twelve patriarchs, from whose lineage the entire nation of the Israelites was propagated. According to the Apostle Paul, the remnants were saved by the election of grace, adding that God did not reject His people.

We should understand the twelve patriarchs as being represented by the same number of gates. Remember, it is not you who support the root, but the root that supports you. It clearly says, the names of the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel were written. Hence, the Apostle confidently declares: They are my kinsmen according to the flesh, who are Israelites. To them belong the adoption as sons, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the service of God, and the promises. The fathers are theirs, and from them is Christ, according to the flesh, who is over all, God blessed forever.

The angels here signify those elders and leaders by whose guidance and governance that nation was wonderfully ruled. If we remember that they are often called gods, it is not surprising if we believe they are called angels. It says, they will be brought to the gods; and, I said, you are gods, and all of you are sons of the Most High, reflecting the entirety of the whole people, which consists of leaders and people.

There are three gates to the east, three gates to the north, three gates to the south, and three gates to the west. This makes twelve, a number often sacredly suggested to us through the apostles and their seats for the fullness of the whole. It says, you will sit with me on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel. For the odd number three, when multiplied by the even number four, makes twelve.

It follows: And the wall of the city has twelve foundations, and on them are the names of the twelve apostles of the Lamb. After mentioning the patriarchs, he remembers the apostles.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Since we know that the Church has only one foundation, which is Christ, we shouldn't be disturbed by the statement that it has twelve foundations here. The apostles deserved to be the foundations of the Church in Christ, about whom the Apostle says: First Corinthians 3: "No one can lay any foundation other than the one already laid, which is Jesus Christ."

The apostles are also described as light in Him when it is said to them: Matthew 5: "You are the light of the world," even though Christ, the true light that enlightens every person coming into this world: John 1: "is the sun."

Thus, Christ is the illuminating light, and they are the illuminated light. The holy Scripture frequently hints at many things similar to those said to us.

Indeed, the Apostle James says: James 1: "He chose to give us birth through the word of truth, that we might be a kind of firstfruits of all he created."

However, the Apostle Paul confidently says: First Corinthians 4: "In Christ Jesus, I became your father through the gospel."

God generates through the adoption of grace, and Paul generates in Christ either through the administration of the sacrament or through the preaching of doctrine, mindful of the divine admonition that says: Matthew 23: "Do not call anyone on earth 'father,' for you have one Father, and he is in heaven."

Similarly, with teachers, Paul also says elsewhere: First Corinthians 1: "Was Paul crucified for you? Were you baptized in the name of Paul?" so that he might direct the intention and hope of all the faithful away from all others and firmly fix it on God with sound doctrine.

In this sense, the psalm: Psalm 120 also sings, saying: "I lift up my eyes to the mountains-where does my help come from?" wishing the mountains to be understood as the apostles and prophets, whom Christ, the Sun of Righteousness, primarily illuminated. And lest it be thought that he trusted in names, he immediately added: "My help comes from the Lord, the Maker of heaven and earth" (Psalm 120).

Just as we should recognize the twelve foundations as apostles, they are all called in the one foundation of Jesus Christ. This pertains to the fact that here, too, the name of the Lamb is not silent, saying: "And on them were the names of the twelve apostles and the Lamb."
chunks.original_latin:

(Joan I). Christus itaque lumen illuminans, illi autem

Scriptura sancta frequenter insinuat. Jacobus denique
 apostolus dicit (Jac I): Voluntarie genuit nos
verbo veritatis, ut simus initium aliquod creaturae
ejus. Securus tamen Paulus apostolus praebendi (Sic)
alloquitur dicens (I Cor IV): In Christo Jesu per
Evangelium ego vos genui. Generat autem Deus per

doctrinae, memor tamen divinae admonitionis, quae

Auxilium meum a Domino, qui fecit coelum et terram
(Psal CXX). Sicut etiam hic duodecim fundamenta

Christo vocatos debemus agnoscere. Ad hoc pertinet

super ea nomina duodecim apostolorum et Agni.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The foundation of the apostles is one with Jesus. Only Christ, without the apostles, is rightly called the foundation. The apostles, without Christ, cannot be called the foundation of the Church.

Similarly, the principles we considered here apply for comparison. The apostles, being faithful in Christ, deserved to spiritually nurture those whom Christ alone, if He wished, would adopt without them.

They also deserved to be teachers and shepherds of the people in Christ, but their service was devoted to the heavenly Father, their ultimate teacher and shepherd.

According to the measure of grace given to them by Christ, He possessed unique natural power. As the Gospel says, "For God does not give the Spirit by measure" (John 3:34). In Him, all the fullness of divinity dwells bodily (Colossians 2:9), and from His fullness, we have all received (John 1:16), and grace upon grace.

It follows: "And the one who was speaking with me had a golden measuring rod to measure the city and its gates and its walls. The city was laid out as a square, its length as great as its width." Earlier, John says a measuring rod was given to him, symbolizing the dispensation of preaching entrusted to him. Now he says the angel speaking with him had a golden measuring rod to measure the city, its gates, and walls.

This must be understood as Christ, who is the wisdom of God (First Corinthians 1:24), reaching from one end to the other mightily and arranging all things sweetly (Wisdom 8:1). As we read in Proverbs 16:16, "Acquire wisdom like gold."

Indeed, only Christ is allowed to measure the city, distributing the gifts of grace to each of the faithful spiritually. As we read, He arranged all things in number, measure, and weight (Wisdom 11:20). This is the dimension of the city mentioned by the Apostle when he says (Ephesians 4:7), "According to the measure of Christ's gift;" and again (Ephesians 3:8), "To me, the very least of all saints, this grace was given to preach to the Gentiles."

 Ecclesiae nullatenus dicentur. Sic etiam caetera
quae huic loco comparationis gratia putavimus
applicanda. Meruerunt enim illi in Christo fideles
spiritaliter generare, quos sine ipsis solus Christus,
si vellet, incomparabiliter adoptaret. Meruerunt
etiam populorum in Christo esse magistri atque pastores,
sed ut coelesti Patri, magistro atque pastori
eorum servitus militaret. Illi ergo secundum mensuram
quam eis partitus est Christus beneficio Domini
sui, ipse autem Christus potentia singulariter naturali,
de quo dictum in Evangelio meminimus. Non
enim ad mensuram dat Deus spiritum (Joan III), in

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The city is set in a perfect square, with equal dimensions on all sides, symbolizing its perfection. As the Apostle says in 1 Corinthians chapter one, to be perfect is to be of the same mind and to have peace, truly represented by the solid square. This is the city built upon a mountain, founded upon itself, as the Lord declares in the Gospel of Matthew chapter five. He also says to Peter, who represents the entire Church in Matthew chapter sixteen: "You are Peter, and on this rock I will build my Church." It's as if He were saying: "Upon myself, I will build you." For the rock was Christ: thus, from the rock comes Peter, just as from Christ comes the Christian. This teaches us to avoid human errors and to follow the strongholds of divine truth.

"And he measured," it says, "the city with a reed, twelve thousand stadia in length, width, and height are equal." This signifies the solidity of invincible truth, by which the Church of Christ is firmly supported and not swayed by every wind of doctrine, as stated in Ephesians chapter four. The number twelve, when multiplied, makes one hundred and forty-four; for twelve times twelve makes one hundred and forty-four. It continues: "The wall was measured to be one hundred and forty-four cubits, the measure of a man, which is that of an angel." The frequent references to places show that the angel often represents the Church. Since the Church consists of people and is elevated by the promises of Christ, it hopes for equality with the angels and longs for their company.

Therefore, it says "the measure of a man, which is that of an angel," either because that city partly consists of angels already dwelling there in perpetual happiness, and partly of pilgrims, that is, people, who will fully reign. Alternatively, it could mean that the number of fallen humans removed from the heavenly abode of the angels is believed to be restored by the number of the redeemed. It will easily be replaced with greater abundance, not diminished. Hence, it is sung in Deuteronomy chapter thirty-two: "He set the boundaries of the peoples according to the number of the angels of God," etc.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
And the construction of its wall was made from jasper stone.

Blessed Peter exhorts the people in First Peter Chapter 2 to be built up like living stones into a spiritual house.

It continues: The city itself was made of pure gold, like clear glass.

Furthermore, it mentions things that seem inappropriate to emphasize the unique dignity of Christ, comparing Him to all other stones. For who does not know that gold differs from glass in quality and color?

Although it is not new for the Church to be symbolized by gold, which is often described in golden candlesticks and bowls for the worship of wisdom, what stands out here is that pure gold is compared to clear glass. I think this signifies what the Apostle said in First Corinthians Chapter 4: Do not judge before the time comes, until the Lord comes, who will bring to light the hidden things of darkness and reveal the thoughts of the heart. For in glass, nothing is shown on the outside except what is contained inside.

Therefore, announcing that time when thoughts will be clearly revealed to each other, confidently compares gold to glass. Whatever is in the thoughts of the saints then, will shine with the beauty of wisdom, which rightly deserves this comparison. For now, no matter how much one excels in virtue, no one knows the innermost thoughts of a person except the spirit of the person within him, as stated in First Corinthians Chapter 2.

Alternatively, it could mean that glass, in its own way, stands out prominently in its kind.

The foundations, however, were made of every precious stone. And in the song of Tobit, Chapter 13, we read: All your walls are made of precious stones.

And in Isaiah Chapter 54 it says: Behold, I will lay your stones in order, and I will lay your foundations with sapphires, and I will make your fortifications with jasper, and your gates with carved stones, and all your borders with desirable stones. To explain what he was saying so that you do not think carnally about the earthly structure, he added in Isaiah Chapter 45: All your children will be taught by the Lord, and great will be the peace of your children, etc.

Blessed Paul, harmonizing with these thoughts, says in Ephesians.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: Built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, with Christ Jesus himself as the chief cornerstone, the whole building grows into a holy temple in the Lord. The first foundation is jasper. Previously, this was mentioned, but now, listing them one by one, it elaborates on the foundations of every precious stone. The second is sapphire; the third, chalcedony; the fourth, emerald; the fifth, sardonyx; the sixth, sardius; the seventh, chrysolite; the eighth, beryl; the ninth, topaz; the tenth, chrysoprase; the eleventh, jacinth; the twelfth, amethyst. These stones symbolize the virtues by which each of the saints is spiritually adorned; and the entire city is described as firm in strength and adorned with variety as if made of these stones. The twelve gates are each made of a single pearl. We have said more than enough about the one foundation of Christ and the twelve apostles of the Lamb, which also applies to the one pearl, that is, Christ, which the merchant found and sold all to buy. It is fitting for the reader to consider the twelve as well. The streets are of pure gold, like transparent glass. It has already been said that the city is of pure gold, like clear glass, or that its foundations are of every precious stone. I think this refers to the powerful ones of the Church. Now, he adds about the streets, saying even they are of pure gold like transparent glass, as if the streets were not part of the previously described city; but here, I infer that the little ones are signified, of whom it is now said (Psalm 139): "Your eyes saw my unformed substance; in your book were written, every one of them." Likewise (Proverbs 3), "And his conversation is with the simple," meaning that they too are not deprived of this gift, and they contemplate their thoughts in mutual exchange. Just as the streets are placed in a lower position, so these seem to be saved in a humble place: but if in the streets the breadth of charity is to be understood, he wished to signify the perfect ones with different terms.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Then, however, no one there will be unworthy. No child or weak person will be found, although some may shine more brightly in rewards than others. As the Apostle says in 1 Corinthians 15, "One star differs from another star in glory," so too is the resurrection of the dead.

I did not see a temple in it, for the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple. Just as a body is built with individual members, so is the temple with precious stones. Since He does not want us to be attached to material structures, thinking of something physical out of habit, He says, "I did not see a temple in it, for the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple."

The Church, especially with the weeds now removed, rejoicing in the chosen ones alone, remains consecrated in the Lord. It rests more securely as in a temple, so that from Him who gave it its origin and experienced the gentleness of redemption, it may also obtain a blessed dwelling. For its entire fulfillment is in these three things: to exist, to know, to love.

God created it to be formed, illuminated it when called, and blessed it when chosen, making it perfect by His promised glorification. No longer walking by faith, but rejoicing in sight. And the city, he says, does not need the sun and the moon to shine on it; for the glory of God illuminates it, and its lamp is the Lamb.

Wishing to completely detach us from the usual alternation of day and night light and to bring us back to that unchangeable light, He says, "it does not need the sun and the moon." He does not claim that the city is illuminated in the same manner, but by a much better and ineffable light, namely the Sun of righteousness, which the prophet refers to in Malachi 4: "And healing in its wings."

He is the true Son, and eternal life, and the true light that enlightens every man coming into this world, as stated in John 1.

What no eye has seen, no ear has heard, nor has it entered into the heart of man in this age, as stated in 1 Corinthians.

<speak>
    
        It couldn't be explained better than this: The brightness of the Lord illuminates it, and its lamp is the Lamb. What greater gift could be given to the victor than to possess the giver of gifts himself? They will enjoy the same light in their homeland that guides us on our path now. <break time="500ms"/> Illuminated by this light, we distinguish between good and evil, and once blessed, we will see only what is good. <break time="500ms"/> The nations will walk by its light, and the kings of the earth will bring their glory into it. <break time="500ms"/> This means that the same Lamb is the way for travelers and will be life for citizens. <break time="500ms"/> Whatever dignity they attain, they must honor the giver with due praises. <break time="500ms"/> Here, the kings are called spiritual, as we read: He is powerful and gives strength to our kings and has exalted the horn of His Christ First Samuel 2. <break time="500ms"/> And its gates will not be closed during the day, for there will be no night there. <break time="500ms"/> The eternal light of the Lamb, the everlasting light itself, will be present in that city when the time of night is removed, as Isaiah says: It will be for them month after month, and Sabbath after Sabbath, signifying light in the month due to the full brightness of the moon, and perpetual rest on the Sabbath. <break time="500ms"/> As if to say: light from light will be continuous, and eternal rest will follow rest. <break time="500ms"/> The fact that the gates will not be closed signifies complete security. <break time="500ms"/> There, it is no longer said, Matthew 26, "Watch and pray, so that you do not fall into temptation," but rather, Psalm 46, "Be still and know that I am God." <break time="500ms"/> There, what is seen is loved honorably, and what is loved is praised without end; there, no one withers in idleness, nor is anyone fatigued by continuous praise. <break time="500ms"/> They will bring the honor and majesty of the nations into it because it will be gathered from all nations. <break time="500ms"/> And nothing unclean will enter it, nor anyone who does what is detestable, but only those who are written in the Lamb's book of life.
